body.title: HTML HOME
body.paragraph: HTML is the standard markup language for Web pages.

body.title: HTML Headings
body.paragraph: HTML headings are titles or subtitles that you want to display on a webpage.

body.title: HTML Attributes
body.paragraph: An HTML attribute provides additional information about an HTML element.

body.title: HTML Elements
body.paragraph:
An HTML element is defined by a start tag, some content, and an 
end tag.

body.title: HTML Basic
body.paragraph: In this chapter we will show some basic HTML examples.

body.title: HTML Colors
body.paragraph: HTML colors are specified using predefined color names, or RGB, HEX, HSL, RGBA, HSLA values.

body.title: HTML Formatting
body.paragraph: HTML contains several elements for defining text with a special meaning.

body.title: HTML Comments
body.paragraph:
HTML comments are not displayed in the browser, but they can 
help document your HTML source code.

body.title: HTML Quotations
body.paragraph:
In this chapter we will go through the <q>, <blockquote>, <abbr>, <address>, <cite>, 
and <bdo> HTML elements.

body.title: HTML Styles
body.paragraph: The HTML style attribute is used to add styles to an element, such as color, font, size, and more.

body.title: HTML Paragraphs
body.paragraph: A paragraph always starts on a new line, and is usually a block of text.

body.title: HTML CSS
body.paragraph: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.

body.title: HTML Editors
body.paragraph: A simple text editor is all you need to learn HTML.

body.title: HTML Introduction
body.paragraph: HTML is the standard markup language for creating Web pages.

body.title: HTML Computercode
body.paragraph:
HTML contains several elements for defining user input and 
computer code.

body.title: HTML Responsive
body.paragraph: Responsive web design is about creating web pages that look good on all devices!

body.title: HTML Layout
body.paragraph: Websites often display content in multiple columns (like a magazine or newspaper).

body.title: HTML Certificate
body.paragraph: W3Schools offers an Online Certification Program.

body.title: HTML Exercises
body.paragraph: You can test your HTML skills with W3Schools' Exercises.

body.title: HTML Quiz
body.paragraph: You can test your HTML skills with W3Schools' Quiz.

body.title: HTML SSE
body.paragraph: Server-Sent Events (SSE) allow a web page to get updates from a server.

body.title: HTML Web Workers
body.paragraph: A web worker is a JavaScript running in the background, without affecting the performance of the page.

body.title: HTML Web Storage
body.paragraph: HTML web storage; better than cookies.

body.title: HTML Drag/Drop
body.paragraph: In HTML, any element can be dragged and dropped.

body.title: HTML Geolocation
body.paragraph: The HTML Geolocation API is used to locate a user's position.

body.title: HTML YouTube
body.paragraph: The easiest way to play videos in HTML, is to use YouTube.

body.title: HTML Plug-ins
body.paragraph: Plug-ins are computer programs that extend the standard functionality of the browser.

body.title: HTML Audio
body.paragraph:
The HTML <audio> element is used to 
play an audio file on a web page.

body.title: HTML Video
body.paragraph:
The HTML <video> element is used to 
show a video on a web page.

body.title: HTML Media
body.paragraph: Multimedia on the web is sound, music, videos, movies, and animations.

body.title: HTML SVG
body.paragraph: SVG defines vector-based graphics in XML format.

body.title: HTML Canvas
body.paragraph: The HTML <canvas> element is used to draw graphics on a web page.

body.title: HTML Form Elements
body.paragraph: This chapter describes all the different HTML form elements.

body.title: HTML Forms
body.paragraph:
An HTML form is used to collect user input. The user input can 
then be sent to a server for processing.

body.title: HTML vs. XHTML
body.paragraph: XHTML is a stricter, more XML-based version of HTML.

body.title: HTML URL Encode
body.paragraph: A URL is another word for a web address.

body.title: HTML Charset
body.paragraph:
To display an HTML page correctly, a web browser must know 
which character set to use.

body.title: HTML Emojis
body.paragraph: Emojis are characters from the UTF-8 character set: 😄 😍 💗

body.title: HTML Symbols
body.paragraph: Characters that are not present on your keyboard can also be replaced by entities.

body.title: HTML Entities
body.paragraph: Reserved characters in HTML must be replaced with character entities.

body.title: HTML Style Guide
body.paragraph: A consistent, clean, and tidy HTML code makes it easier for others to read and understand your code.

body.title: HTML Semantics
body.paragraph: Semantic elements = elements with a meaning.

body.title: HTML Head
body.paragraph:
The HTML <head> element
is a container for all the head elements:
<title>, <style>, 
<meta>, <link>, <script>, and <base>.

body.title: HTML File Paths
body.paragraph: A file path describes the location of a file in a web site's folder structure.

body.title: HTML JavaScript
body.paragraph: JavaScript makes HTML pages more dynamic and interactive.

body.title: HTML Iframes
body.paragraph: An HTML iframe is used to display a web page within a web page.

body.title: HTML Id
body.paragraph:
The HTML id attribute is used 
to specify a unique id for an HTML element (the value must be unique within the 
HTML document).

body.title: HTML Classes
body.paragraph:
The HTML class attribute is 
used to define equal styles for elements with the same class name.

body.title: HTML Blocks
body.paragraph:
Every HTML element has a default display value, depending on what type 
of element it is.

body.title: HTML Lists
body.paragraph: HTML lists allow web authors to group a set of related items in lists.

body.title: HTML Tables
body.paragraph:
HTML tables allow web authors to arrange data into rows and 
columns.

body.title: HTML Images
body.paragraph: Images can improve the design and the appearance of a web page.

body.title: HTML Links
body.paragraph: Links are found in nearly all web pages. Links allow users to click their way from page to page.
